events.name: Event One: Working @ Google
events.description:
GDG Waterloo

Three speakers, 20 minutes each. Five minute breaks in between and 45 minutes of Q&A, meet-and-greet, and activities after.

This month: Working @ Google

We've got two great speakers lined up including James Campbell, the hiring manager at Google KW, and Tonia Tong, who interned with Google in San Fransisco. Both will be going over the things they did to stand out from the pack, get hired, and be a Googler.

John Rockefeller will also be presenting a code walk-through of launching your first PHP app on Google App Engine.

See you there!

events.name: Nano Code Jam
events.description:
• "Oculus Rift on HTML5 using Node.js" by John Rockefeller

• "Android Quick Start" by Imad Azzam

• "OAuth2 on Android" by Norm Young

• "HTML5 Animation" by Alicia Thomson

We'll all break into small teams to develop nano-sized applications demonstrating one or more of Google's APIs. Each team will show their stuff with quick demos at the end of the evening.

Bring your laptop and come to lead or learn about Google's software technologies by putting your hands in to develop the code. Be sure to sign up for an account at GitHub, if you don't have one already (you do, RIGHT?)

Suggest your API and app ideas in the comments. Volunteer to lead a team. Mention which nano-project you'd like to join.

<b style="font-size : 14px">Android Quick Start

This is for developers that are completely new to Android, or have very little experience with it. I will go over select basic topics from here: http://developer.android.com/training/index.html and one advanced topic (In-App Billing), time-permitting.

The topics covered will be enough to put together a fully functional app, for example, my first Android app found on Google Play here:http://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=azzam.imad.games.silhouguess2

Prerequisites:

1- Download and install the Android SDK from here: http://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html

2- Once installed, download the API 16 packages as follows:

a- Open Eclipse from the SDK downloaded above

b- Go to Window --> Android SDK Manager --> Select 'Android 4.1.2 (API 16)', which automatically select everything under it.

c- Make sure everything else is not selected, click 'Install ## packages' and follow the prompts.

3- If possible, bring an Android device running Android 4.1.2 or higher, and an appropriate USB cable. Running and debugging on a real device are much faster and convenient than the simulator.

OAuth2 on Android

From the top, down...

• Android Apps on Web APIs: http://youtu.be/dylFNrvZ_3U

• Overview of OAuth2: http://youtu.be/YLHyeSuBspI

• Jump to Mobile: http://youtu.be/YLHyeSuBspI?t=28m42s

• Authorization on Android: http://developer.android.com/google/play-services/auth.html

• Getting started: https://developers.google.com/.../oauth-and-tasks-on-android

• Official sample: http://code.google.com/.../OAuth2#Android

• Unofficial sample: https://github.com/wareninja/generic-oauth2-login-for-android

events.name: Working with JavasCript and jQuery
events.description:
We're teaming up with GDG Toronto in our first of four parts which will culminate in a road-trip to T.O. for a hackjam!

This first event is a primer on JavaScript and jQuery. We've got a few great tips and tricks as well as a ton of best-practice advice for everyone's favourite language: JS.

NOTE: BRING YOUR LAPTOP FOR THIS EVENT. WE'LL BE WORKING THROUGH CODE TOGETHER! Github account + favourite text editor would be awesome, too.

Be sure to attend each event in order to have a good handle on the hackjam (unless you're some sort of JavaScript master, that is...!)

See you then!

events.name: Everything you've ever wanted to know about JavaScript functions, and more
events.description:
King of JavaScript, Adam Merrifield of seyDoggy Systems, has offered to step up and walk us through how functions work in JavaScript. 

He'll cover

• function expressions vs declarations

• named vs anonymous

• hoisting

• constructors

• protoypes

• patterns

• functions as objects

Adam is also the person who graciously offered us booking space at The Matrix room for the next few JavaScript events. Without his assistance, we would not be able to pull this off. Thanks Adam!

events.name: jQuery.tellAll();
events.description:
I'm going to mimic Adam's awesome work with JavaScript functions from the last meetup and do something similar for jQuery. jQuery is an amazing library. In my opinion, it's done for JavaScript what PHP did for server-side websites: made their development rapid so developers can iterate and validate quickly.

If you're wondering what happened to "Backbone.js and Underscore.js" meetup, I've moved it to next week as quite a few people have asked for some more in-depth information on jQuery before we move forward.

http://jquery.com/
events.how_to_find_us: Yell our name really really loud

events.name: JavaScript MVC with Backbone.js and Underscore.js
events.description:
We're focusing on the MVC framework Backbone.js and it's handy-dandy partner, Underscore.js. Using these two, combined with Require.js and Node.js, you can build MVC apps right in the browser that run on the client.

Note: this event replaces the "JavaScript for mobile devices" event that was listed here previously. We did not have a speaker for that event and I am not well-versed enough to speak on it, so instead I've moved the Backbone.js one to this time slot. I apologize if you really really really wanted to know the mobile stuff. If you know someone in the industry with the right experience and understanding, PLEASE get in contact as we can always do it in a future event.

events.name: JavaScript Code Jam with GDG Toronto
events.description:
NOTE: THIS EVENT IS IN TORONTO! COORDINATE WITH OTHER GROUP MEMBERS OR GROUP LEADERS FOR RIDES!

We're going on a road trip! Exciting!

We'll be meeting up with the folks from GDG Toronto to do a JavaScript code jam. We'll use all the skills we've built thus far to put together some awesome JavaScript apps.

Can't wait!

events.name: The MEAN Stack
events.description:
Our very own Kurt DaCosta will be walking us through building a server-side JavaScript app on the MEAN stack! If you've been hearing about server-side JavaScript and Node but haven't had the chance to really get into it, you will not want to miss this one.

MONGODB - EXPRESSJS - ANGULARJS - NODEJS

Bring your laptop! We're going to code along with Kurt.

events.name: Wakanda, the Data Focussed JavaScript Stack
events.description:
Greg McCarvell of Wakanda is going to walk us through building then deploying a Wakanda-built JS app to a VPS. If you're into server-side JS with tools like Node and npm, you will definitely not want to miss this!

On Wakanda

Server side JavaScript has made an impact in recent years. The Wakanda platform began development in 2008 and takes a decidedly different approach from Node.js in it's implementation. See how this tightly integrated stack including a relational NoSQL Datastore, an industrial grade webserver and client side framework work together to tackle business applications.

events.name: Google API Hackathon
events.description:
You want APIs? Google's got em by the fistful.

If you've been itching to build something in a fast-paced, time-crunched environment, to show off your skills or to flesh out your resume, we want you to come to this event, laptop in-hand.

Let's set the stage. You've got 8 hours, free project hosting, a collection of 14 other talented people to work with, (possibly) some really amazing hardware to play with, and a really snazzy prize (to be announced) to compete for.

We're doing five (count 'em, five.) hackathons per year, with two more after this to be schedule at a later date. This is our first this year and first as a group.

Who can come? Participation is limited to 15 due to time, scope, and the size of the space we've got. We're looking for passionate people of any skill level who play well with others to come out and build something awesome with Google APIs.

What are the rules? Pretty simple:

• Projects and pages should be hosted using Google App Engine and Google Sites. Both are completely free and work great.

• All projects should be libre software or open-source and preferably hosted on GitHub (BitBucket and others work fine too)

• All projects must use a Google API in a fresh and unique way

• Judging of the winner will be by popular vote by other participants

events.name: Android:  Installing the Development Tools
events.description:
Thanks to the makers at KwartzLabs for allowing us the use of their premises.
Topics we will attempt to cover include: Installing the JDK. (Java Development Kit), Which IDE to Choose, Installing Eclipse, Installing Android Studio. Using the SDK Manager. Using the Emulator and Physical Android Devices. Building and running the SDK Samples.

events.name: #2 - Hello Android - Building Your First App
events.description: In this session we will introduce the four kinds of components that may be combined to make an app and then we'll create a simple app. We'll discuss some features and history of the Android OS, explore the different versions in use and how to use the SDK Manager to download the various platforms. We'll see how to create a virtual device to test and debug our projects on.

events.name: 3 - Projects, Modules, Folders and Files
events.description: We'll begin by looking at the key programs and directories that make up Android Studio and the SDK. We'll give an overview of managing projects and touch on the major module types found in a project. Then we'll examine the files and directories that make up a typical project. We'll discuss fragments and how they relate to activities and see how resources are handled and how they support different devices and localization.

events.name: 4 - Intents, Activities, Fragments and Accessing Web Data
events.description: This session we'll examine one of the unique features of the Android OS that allow for interaction between apps - Intents. We'll also look at the usage of fragments and activities and the relations between them. We'll also have a presentation on hooking up your Sunshine app to the web to retrieve the latest weather data.

events.name: 5 - More on Intents, Intent Filters & App Permissions
events.description: This time we'll cover Common Intents.  We'll see how to create Intent Filters and add them to our app.  We'll test our apps response to specific implicit intents using the Activity Manager.  We'll look at how "Google Now" uses voice commands to initiate actions via Intents.

events.name: 6 - Using Studio more Effectively
events.description: This time we'll look at some of the time saving features that studio provides such as refactoring, code completion via picklists and more.

events.name: 9 - Android - Browsing the System Source Code
Expert Android Developers Speak
events.description:
Jake Wharton and Jesse Wilson will be presenting.

NOTE:  Attendees should go to the main entrance of the building (to the right of the Google lobby entrance) and take the elevator to the 4th floor.

Jake Wharton - Android Development with Kotlin

Using Kotlin for Android development has grown in popularity over the last year. Even to those who are not currently using it, the value proposition of the language immediately resonates. There already are a lot of introductory talks to the language and its extensions for use on Android. This talk will cover advancing the usage and design patterns of the language for Android development to solve larger problems. While the content is targeted at mobile development, there will be value for all Java developers interested in Kotlin.

Prior knowledge or use of Kotlin is not required to attend this talk. Some concepts of the language will be used without introduction but they are intuitive and/or quickly learned. Even if you don't fully understand every language concept on which each example is built, the resulting functionality will be clear.

Jesse Wilson - JNI Hello World

A quick look at what JNI is, how it works, and how you can use it to be awesome.

events.name: Study Jam #1 - Android for Beginners (Kitchener)
events.description: Join us for the first of five sessions. The course is based on Udacity's Android for Beginners course which you are asked to enroll in via this link -> https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

events.name: Study Jam #2 - Android - Building App Layouts
events.description:
Have you got what it takes to learn how to be an Apptrepeneur?

Join us for the second of five sessions. For this session you are expected to have covered the course material (videos & quizes) in sections 1A and 1B which cover Building Layouts as well as attempting to make your first app "Birthday Card". 

In this session we will recap what you learned, answer any questions and time permitting we will touch on some more advanced topics.

Participants are encouraged to join the Global Study Jam Student G+ community via this link ->

https://plus.google.com/u/0/communities/107779414017676143474

This course is based on Udacity's Android for Beginners course which you are asked to enroll in via this link -> https://www.udacity.com/account/affiliate/GoogleStudyJams

events.name: Explore the Physical Web and Origin Trials
events.description:
The first talk will begin with an explanation of BLE (Bluetooth Low Energy) and Advertisement Packets. It will then explore what Bluetooth Beacons are and how they can be used to enable the Physical Web. There will be some demos followed by a Q/A period.

The second presentation, Origin Trials, is a new way to enable web developers to try out new features such as the Web Bluetooth API. When enabled on Chrome this will allow you to scan for and connect to Bluetooth devices. Developers are invited to try out this API and provide feedback on the spec and/or implementation.

Thanks to Michal and Jason of Google for providing this content.

events.name: Discover the new Firebase
events.description:
A few short weeks ago Google announced Firebase, a mobile platform that helps you quickly develop high-quality apps, grow your user base, and earn more money. This session will give you an overview of the new Firebase, its SDKs and how you can use Firebase to build better apps and grow your business.

Speaker:
Syed Salman Qadri is a Product Manager in the Developer Product Group, leading the strategy for the Firebase SDKs (Android, IOS, Web). Prior to Google, Salman lead mobile engineering at Yahoo Games and Flurry.

*Note: Please use this registration link*.

events.name: Evening of playtesting and constructive feedback between game professionals.
events.description:
On June 28th, studios and moonlighting industry professionals from southwestern Ontario and beyond will be gathering at Hacker Studios for an evening of playtesting and constructive feedback between game professionals.

“Game Slice” is London’s first sneak preview event showcasing vertical slices, alphas, betas and release candidates. This event is the first of its kind, intended to make the game development community stronger via networking and testing one another’s games.

EVENT DETAILS

- Who: Any professional of the game industry, as well as who would like to either playtest games or showcase his/her own game. Students welcome, 19+, Free participation (and prizes) but Mandatory RSVP
- What: 4-hour free playtesting of local games currently in development, licensed refreshments provided

ATTEND THE EVENT AS A GAME CREATOR (SHOWCASER) - REGISTER BEFORE JUNE 13TH
Every digital game creator is invited to register to get a free booth to present his/her game at the event, rough uncomplete games are encouraged! ===> Mandatory registration is required: gameslice.eventbrite.com

This event is organized by London-based game studio Mikutech and presented by sponsored by Montreal International Gaming Summit (MIGS).

events.name: The Kubernetes Platform
events.description:
Learn about container orchestration at scale with Kubernetes.

Kubernetes 1.0 was an MVP (Minimum Viable Product) developed by Google for running stateless apps in a single cluster. Now, 3 releases later, we're building on that foundation to do things like run stateful, data-heavy applications, and to federate clusters together for global low latency, high availability apps. In short, we're letting you run like Google, whoever and wherever you are.  Come along to learn a little of the Kubernetes history, and some specifics about new features including stateful application (PetSets) and cluster federation.

Speaker Bio:

Craig Box helps make Google's compute platform available to you. He started his career as a systems administrator, and has worked in development, deployment, DevOps, consulting, advisory and management roles. Craig earned his Computer Science degree at the University of Waikato, and has over 15 years industry experience across North America, EMEA and APAC, including 2 years working in Kitchener!

Note:

We are doing this talk together with Dev Ops Waterloo and the Docker Waterloo meetup groups, so please RSVP early.

events.name: Inaugural GDG Waterloo AI Meetup
events.description:
Starting this July, we'll be hosting AI and ML themed talks/meetups throughout the year! Waterloo Region has a thriving data community, that we want to create more of a community around.

Our first events talks will be:
Data pipelines in AI for SaaS applications - Mary Loubele, MappedIn
Slaying the Scalability and Explainability Beasts In Deep Learning - Alex Wong, Associate Professor and Canada Research Chair at University of Waterloo

Following each talk will be a fireside Q&A!
events.how_to_find_us: Look for the signs on Breithaupt!

events.name: Android Dev Summit Viewing Party

venue.name: Cineplex Kitchener Cinemas & VIP
venue.address_1: 225 Fairway Road South Kitchener, ON, N2C 1X2

events.description:
***PLEASE REGISTER HERE >>>>> https://events.withgoogle.com/android-dev-summit-viewing-parties/
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Join the experience in a movie theater to watch live stream summit at the viewing party.

We reserved your spot for the Android Dev Summit viewing party at Cineplex Cinemas VIP in Kitchener. You will get to see the live event taking place in many other cities at the same time.

While you're watching the sessions live, you'll meet other developers and learn about the new Android updates. There will be food and a great atmosphere. Come and join the party.

events.name: Flutter Live'18
events.description:
NOTE ***Make sure to signup to this event at https://www.eventbrite.com/e/flutter-live18-tickets-52979427895 we don't accept registrations through this group!

Description
Join us for Flutter Live on December 4th to experience the latest from Flutter, Google’s free and open source SDK for building high-quality native iOS and Android apps from a single codebase.

Presented from the Science Museum in London, but we are optimizing Flutter Live to reach the largest audience of mobile developers and provide all the rigor and excitement of an in-person experience to our global online audience.

The presentation will be shown here at the Google Kitchener Campus - Community Space and starts at 12:00 AM, but we invite you to come a little early.

Livestream:
Flutter Live is all about our online audience. With viewing parties happening around the world and exclusive content during the event, we will make sure you can tune in from anywhere to watch.

Speakers:
You will hear directly from the Flutter team, external partners, and other Googlers with demos, technical content, and updates. Wherever you are, there will be a chance to engage with the community, ask questions, and share what you have been building with Flutter.

Code Lab Session: Firebase for Flutter Code

Codelab prerequisites: Familiarity with object-oriented programming concepts should be able to complete this session.

Parking:
***Please be advised that parking at the front of the building is strictly prohibited, and will be ticketed.

Paid parking spaces are available and are shown in the map below:

events.name: GDG Waterloo AI: Computer Vision

venue.name: Shopify
venue.address_1: 57 Erb St W, Waterloo, ON N2L 6C2

events.description:
This December we'll be hosting a variety of speakers around computer vision and it's applications. Below are our speakers and a description of their talks!

Adler Santos, Data Engineer at Skywatch Space Applications
Satellite imagery varies greatly in quality – some images will contain defects introduced by the environment (say your area of interest is covered in clouds) and/or by the image processing algorithm (blurs, artifacts, or gaps are introduced). One of the challenges facing Skywatch is to prevent unusable, low-quality imagery from getting to our customers. In this presentation, I'd like to discuss how we used computer vision for image quality assessment and how it has helped us consistently deliver high-quality satellite imagery to the end-user.

Michael Jamieson, Computer Vision Researcher at SPORTLOGiQ
One of the things we do at SPORTLOGiQ is visually track players in soccer and hockey games. This rich spatial context lets us better understand game events such as passes and turnovers as well as the overall flow of the game. We can track in real time using multiple fixed cameras or work directly from the broadcast feed.

Following each talk will be a fireside Q&A!

events.name: Women Techmakers Waterloo: Presents a Night of Celebration IWD '19
events.description:
*** This event is FREE but please RSVP here: https://bit.ly/2CjiipZ ***

Google's Women Techmakers program provides visibility, community, and resources for women in technology.

In honor of International Women's Day 2019; WTM Waterloo, will be celebrating a diverse group of Women Techmakers from the KW region and their invaluable contributions to technology.

Kindly join us for a night of storytelling, inspiration and celebration of some remarkable local Women Techmakers!

Our #IamRemarkable Speakers:

Amanie Ismail: Co-Founder & COO, Meya.ai
Ashton Rankin: Product Manager, Vidyard
Carolina Miranda:Co-Founder, Feminine Harbor & Educator with WCDSB
Dinah Davis: VP of R&D, Arctic Wolf
Davis Green: Interaction Designer
Komal Singh: Program Manager at Google and Author of "Ara The Star Engineer"
Lori Lalonde: Senior Tech Evangelist, Microsoft
Lisa House: Technical Program Manager, SkyWatch
Mandy Gu: Computational Linguist
Mayya Sharipova: Java Search Engineer, Elastic
Nicole Hu: UX Designer, ApplyBoard

Please note we will be capturing various moments of our celebration. Parking is available in the lot across the building.

events.name: GDG Waterloo presents: Unique Applications of Computer Vision
events.description:
This event will be shedding some light on an interesting project built at TD Lab. Converting hand drawn images to fully functioning mobile apps. Hosted by Applyboard and focusing on the work from TD Lab, we will have the following speakers:

Dexter Fichuk, Natural Language Processing Engineer at Shopify. While working at TD Lab, Dexters passion for Computer Vision drove him to create a pipeline converting hand drawn images to functioning mobile applications.

Omas Abdullah, Software Engineer Team Lead at Applyboard. Prior to Applyboard, Omas worked alongside Dexter at TD Lab where he worked on iOS development. Together with his team they were able to move the full conversion pipeline to run locally on an iPhone. Drastically improving runtime.

Come take a technical dive on how these two were able to apply a unique solution to a problem that many development teams face today.

Following the talk will be a Q&A!
Food and beverages (non alcoholic) will be provided!

events.name: Firebase AB Testing - Intelligently Grow Your App with Experiments
events.description:
In this talk, we will introduce the Firebase Development Platform, discuss how it can help you grow your business and dive into its AB Testing capabilities.

Speaker: David loves building software for solving real-life problems. When not busy writing code or learning new technologies, he enjoys playing guitar and chess. He is currently a software engineer at Google Canada, working on Firebase!

ApplyBoard is the world’s largest online platform for international students to apply to study at the best institutions in Canada and the United States. ApplyBoard’s mission is to empower people around the world to access the best education, driven by the belief that education is a right, not a privilege. With its headquarters in Canada’s Kitchener-Waterloo tech hub and representatives in China, India, Nepal, Vietnam, and Bangladesh, ApplyBoard is a global company that is revolutionizing the way students experience the application process. The company now employs over 200 staff members across its locations.

**Food and drinks will be provided**

To register for the event go to: https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/gdg-waterloo-presents-firebase-ab-testing-intelligently-grow-your-app-with-experiments-tickets-66601309309?utm_term=eventurl_text

events.name: GDG-Waterloo Presents: Unseen Data Collection by Paul Mason
events.description:
Presentation:
Terms of service agreements often make use of lengthy, complicated text, causing us to not only scroll through quickly, but to click 'agree' so we can get on the app right away! But have you ever wondered what personal information is shared each time you download and use an app? How about where your personal information is stored or who has access to it? When you click to 'agree', what exactly are you agreeing to? In this presentation, we'll take a deeper look into cases of unseen data collection!

Speaker:
Paul Mason is currently the Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) at ApplyBoard. With over 32 years of experience in Information Technology Networking and Security Penetration Testing, Paul has been instrumental in delivering security consulting in international markets including Canada and USA. Further, throughout his career he has supported governments and companies such as OMA, CNIB and PointClickCare.

ApplyBoard is the world’s largest online platform for international students to apply to study at the best institutions in Canada and the United States. ApplyBoard’s mission is to empower people around the world to access the best education, driven by the belief that education is a right, not a privilege. With its headquarters in Canada’s Kitchener-Waterloo tech hub and representatives in China, India, Nepal, Vietnam, and Bangladesh, ApplyBoard is a global company that is revolutionizing the way students experience the application process. The company now employs over 200 staff members across its locations.

**Food and drinks will be provided**

Schedule of Event:
6:30-7:15pm: Networking & Food
7:15- 8:00pm: Presentation
8:00-8:30pm: QA
8:30-9:00pm: Networking and Wrap up.
events.how_to_find_us: We are located at the corner of Frederick and Weber (Passport Canada Building). Free parking is available by the Kitchener Public Library across Centre in the Square as well as on Queen St. (just off Duke)

events.name: GDG+KWRuby Present: Building a Career in Technology w/ Rob & Ralph of ApplyBoard
events.description:
GDG - Waterloo in conjunction with KWRuby, invites you to a fireside chat! Join us as for an engaging conversation about Career Development in Tech with Ralph Janke and Rob Sciuk of ApplyBoard.

Speakers:

Rob Sciuk is currently a Senior Software Developer at ApplyBoard. With over 30 years of experience in Information Technology, Rob has been a Founding Principal in a high-tech startup, and has a strong foundation in business, account management and technical project management. In addition, he has been an instrumental Technical Lead in very large projects with multi-million dollar revenues. His specialties include Software Development, Systems Analysis, Software Portability, Scalability, with a particular interest in Embedded and Open Source Software.

Ralph Janke is currently a Director of Software Development at ApplyBoard. Ralph has over 35 years of experience in Information Technology in small, medium and multinational companies, as well as in the public sector. As a leader, he continuously looks to help others within the organization apply and improve their skills by guiding and mentoring them to be positive, motivated, and loyal employees with fulfilling careers.

ApplyBoard empowers students around the world to access the best education. Connecting international students, recruitment partners, and academic institutions on its platform, ApplyBoard simplifies the study abroad search, application, and acceptance process. Founded in 2015, the company has built partnerships with over 1,200 primary, secondary, and post-secondary schools, and works with 3,500 recruitment partners, to drive diversity on campuses across Canada and the United States. To date, the company has assisted more than 65,000 students with their educational journey. ApplyBoard is headquartered in Kitchener, ON Canada, with representatives in 8 countries. For more information, visit www.applyboard.com.

Deloitte named ApplyBoard the Fastest-Growing Technology Company in Canada and they have over 100 positions currently open!
events.how_to_find_us:
**Food and drinks will be provided**

events.name: WTM & GDG -Waterloo Present: Flutter Interact!
events.description:
Join us at Google for Flutter Interact with live announcements of new features associated with Flutter and other related Google technologies. Faisal Abid, Co-Founder of dydx will be facilitating a session on Flutter for Mobile Developers.

Faisal Abid is a Google Developer Expert, Entrepreneur, and Engineer. He is a programming language enthusiast and loves solving software engineering challenges across the stack.

Currently, Faisal is the Co-Founder @ dydx. At any point during the day, you can find Faisal writing mobile apps in Flutter, building backends in Dart, Node.js or Rust, creating models with Tensorflow or deploying services with Kubernetes.

We encourage attendees to bring their laptops for this interactive Flutter session!

Agenda and Schedule

6:00pm-6:30pm Watch Flutter Interact Keynote

6:30pm-6:45pm Break

6:45pm-7:15pm Flutter for Mobile Developers session w/ Faisal Abid

7:45pm-8:00pm Wrap Up

upcoming.name: A Silver Jubilee Celebration of Black History Month powered by WTM-Waterloo
upcoming.description:
Powered by WTM-Waterloo: BlackMaple.io in conjunction with Innovate Inclusion Present: I Am My Ancestors’ Wildest Dreams: A Silver Jubilee Celebration of Black History Month.

Join us for an interactive evening of storytelling, cultural exchange, inspiration and celebration of some remarkable Black Founders, Tech Makers, Entrepreneurs, Creatives and Community Builders!

To register for the event visit: https://wtm-waterloo-bhm.eventbrite.ca/

Our Incomparable Speakers:

Sarah Juma: Founder and Director, Innovate Inclusion

Damola Adepetu: PhD: Manager, Data Science at Loblaw

Akailah Wilson: University Programs Specialist, Google

Jessie Estwick: Content Research Specialist, ApplyBoard

Kasie Maduabunachukwu: Researcher and Developer

Anwar Jeffrey: Software Developer, Bonfire

Alana Arthur: Owner, Freedom Cycle

Rawl Banton: Senior Innovation Advisor, Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada

Sagal Muse: Social Media Strategist, InVision App & Founder and Creative Director, Muse Avenue

Camille Mitchell: Design Architect, Gensler

Alicia Wynter: Owner, Alicia Wynter Photography

....Additional speakers to be announced....

Our Amazing Host:

Naudia Banton: Director of Operations, IntelliFLEX Innovation Alliance

Our Makers Market Includes:

Artisanal Design Co.

Piece of MamaAfrica

Muse Avenue

Freedom Cycle

....Additional markers to be announced....

Schedule:

6:30-7:00pm (Welcome Reception)

7:00-8:30pm (Lightning Talks)

8:30-9:30pm (Wrap Up Reception/Networking)

Note: This event is open to all community members! We will be capturing various moments of our celebration. By attending this event, you consent to being photographed and/or filmed. Food and beverages will be served at the event!

Parking: Available in the lot across from the Google building on Breithaupt Street.
